title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act titled "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006" establishes the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, covering approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a final map and boundary description to Congress, with the map having the same force as the Act. Management of the scenic area is outlined. The Secretary will manage the Mountaintown National Scenic Area to protect scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and wildlife habitat. A management plan must be developed within three years, prioritizing the area's purposes over general National Forest System laws and regulations. After the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will develop a management plan for the scenic area as an amendment to the Chattahoochee National Forest's land and resource management plan. No new roads can be built within the scenic area, except for access to private lands. Timber harvest is prohibited, except for fire control, insect/disease management, public safety, and trail access. The Secretary may conduct vegetation manipulation for wildlife clearings and visual quality, and personal firewood harvesting is allowed. Motorized travel is restricted within the scenic area, except for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires will be suppressed to maintain management purposes. Insect and disease outbreaks may be controlled to preserve scenic quality. Water quality will be maintained or enhanced. Federally owned lands in the scenic area are withdrawn from mining, subject to valid existing rights. "Federally owned lands in the scenic area are withdrawn from mining laws and leasing claims under mineral and geothermal leasing laws of the United States." SEC. 3. DESIGNATION OF ADDITIONAL NATIONAL FOREST SYSTEM LAND AS WILDERNESS IN GEORGIA. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres in Georgia as wilderness areas, including additions to existing Southern Nantahala, Blood Mountain, Brasstown, Ellicott Rock, and Cohutta Wilderness areas. The Wilderness Act designates new wilderness areas in Georgia, including additions to existing Cohutta, Raven Cliffs, and Tray Mountain Wilderness areas. The Secretary will provide final maps and descriptions of the designated lands for public inspection. The lands will be administered in accordance with the Wilderness Act. The Wilderness Act designates new wilderness areas in Georgia, including additions to existing Cohutta, Raven Cliffs, and Tray Mountain Wilderness areas. The designated lands are withdrawn from various forms of entry and disposal under public land laws, mining laws, and laws pertaining to mineral leasing. The effective date of the Wilderness Act is deemed to be the date of enactment of this Act. The State of Georgia retains jurisdiction over fish and wildlife in the Chattahoochee National Forest.
